bestBHT.bht: John, with reverence, chooses not to enter the sepulchre, instinctively noticing the undisturbed linen clothes. Peter, however, unafraid, enters the empty tomb driven by a sense of awe and mystery. It seems unlikely that the body would have been stripped naked, indicating that the linen clothes were not removed by a friend or enemy. John, with his timid nature, hesitates outside, stooping down to look inside but unable to gather the courage to go in alone.

Henry Alford: but when there, reverently (not for fear of pollution, as some have thought) abstains from entering the sepulchre.
Marvin Vincent: He looketh forth at the windows.
John Calvin: The linen clothes might be regarded as the spoils, intended to lead to the belief of Christ’s resurrection.
For it was not probable that his body had been stripped naked, in order that it might be removed to another place.
This would not have been done by a friend, nor even by an enemy.
Philip Schaff: A feeling of awe and mystery in all probability possessed him. He was afraid to enter."
It was not so with Peter.
Archibald T. Robertson: If the body had been removed, these clothes would have gone also.
John's timid nature made him pause.
John notices this fact at once.
John Gill: And he stooping down and looking in,.... That is, John; when he came to the sepulchre, stooped down to look into it, and see what he could see; he only went into the court, or stood upon the floor, where the bearers used to set down the bier, before they put the corpse into one of the graves in the sepulchre, which were four cubits lower; :-. Hence he was obliged to stoop down, ere he could see anything within."
When he saw the linen clothes lying; in which the body had been wrapped, but that itself not there.

Yet went he not in; to the sepulchre itself, but waited in the court or porch, till Peter came; and perhaps might be timorous and fearful of going into such a place alone; the Arabic version reads it, 'he dared not go in'.

bhtAttempts.bht: In the midst of the empty tomb, John stands reverently outside, not out of fear of pollution, but rather with a simple and intent gaze. He notices that the linen clothes lie there undisturbed, a clear indication that the body had not been removed. Peter, however, does not hesitate to enter, driven by a feeling of awe and mystery. It is unlikely that the body would have been stripped naked by friend or foe, making the presence of the linen clothes a significant clue. John, with his timid nature, remains outside, stooping down and peering in, unable to muster the courage to go in alone.

With reverence, John refrains from entering the empty tomb, observing the linen clothes undisturbed. This suggests that the body had not been removed, as it is improbable it would have been stripped naked. Meanwhile, Peter, driven by a sense of awe and mystery, fearlessly enters. John, with his timid nature, remains outside, stooping down to peer inside, unable to gather the courage to go in alone. The presence of the linen clothes serves as a significant clue, indicating that something extraordinary had happened.

With a reverent hesitation, John refrains from entering the tomb but observes the undisturbed linen clothes, which renders it improbable that the body had been stripped naked. On the other hand, Peter, driven by a mixture of awe and fear, fearlessly ventures inside. John, more timid by nature, stoops down to peer in, lacking the courage to go in alone. This presence of the linen clothes serves as an important indication that something extraordinary had occurred.

John, with reverence, chooses not to enter the sepulchre, instinctively noticing the undisturbed linen clothes. Peter, however, unafraid, enters the empty tomb driven by a sense of awe and mystery. It seems unlikely that the body would have been stripped naked, indicating that the linen clothes were not removed by a friend or enemy. John, with his timid nature, hesitates outside, stooping down to look inside but unable to gather the courage to go in alone.

With reverence, John hesitates to enter the sepulchre, noting the undisturbed linen clothes, which suggests the body was not removed. Meanwhile, Peter, driven by awe and mystery, fearlessly goes inside. John, being timid, stoops down to look but doesn't venture in. The presence of the linen clothes is significant evidence that something extraordinary occurred, as it is unlikely they would have been left behind if the body had been taken by a friend or foe.
